article.title: Individual Arrested Following Estero Park Confrontation
article.description: An 18-year-old Isla Vista resident was reportedly arrested in Estero Park Monday night for “obstructing a peace officer."
article.content:
Isla Vista Foot Patrol officers arrested the 18-year-old I.V. resident on Monday night. Sichen Wang/Daily Nexus

An 18-year-old Isla Vista resident was arrested in Estero Park Monday night for “obstructing a peace officer,” according to the Santa Barbara County Sheriff’s Office.

Deputies observed several people arguing in Estero Park at approximately 7:45 p.m. on Monday and attempted to detain the group, concerned that the argument “could turn into a fight,” SBSO spokesperson Kelly Hoover said in an email.

Officers detained Marco Antonio Mendoza after he “attempted to incite” the group to avoid arrest, Hoover said in the email.

Mendoza initially walked away while deputies attempted to detain the other individuals. Deputies then “observed that [Mendoza] had a knife in his back pocket,” Hoover said.

According to Hoover, Mendoza was “argumentative and uncooperative.” He returned to the group and “despite orders that he was being detained, he ignored deputies and attempted to incite the other subjects to walk away and leave,” Hoover said in an email.

Mendoza “delayed the investigation,” which resulted in additional police units arriving on the scene to safely detain the subjects, Hoover said.

He was booked at the Santa Barbara Jail at approximately 9:56 p.m. on a $2,500 bail, according to arrest logs.

There is no student by the name of Marco Mendoza in UC Santa Barbara’s student directory.

Mendoza is not currently a student at Santa Barbara City College and has never registered for classes there, according to SBCC spokesperson Luz Reyes-Martin.

Updated at 9:02 a.m.

Print
Evelyn Spence

Evelyn Spence harbors a great love for em dashes and runs on nothing but iced coffee, Jolly Ranchers and breaking news. She serves as the managing editor and can be reached at evelyn@dailynexus.com, managing@dailynexus.com or at @evelynrosesc on Twitter.

related.title: Vista Point
related.description: Catch up on the goings-on in Isla Vista this week!
related.content:
Sierra Deak/Daily Nexus

Pizza with the Press: Daily Nexus Town Hall

On Thursday, April 12, from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m, the Daily Nexus will be hosting a Town Hall at Rincon Brewery. We want to hear about your questions and concerns regarding our coverage, and we want to open up our reporting process so members of our community have a chance to share their opinions with us. If you feel uncomfortable asking a question in person, there will be an anonymous Google form for any comments or suggestions that you may have. See you there, Gauchos!

Indian Food Tasting

Need a flavor boost, Gauchos? On Thursday, April 12, the Isla Vista Food Co-Op is hosting a HowGood demo with Maya Kaimal Fine Indian Foods from 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. Stop by and try five flavors of ready-made “dal,” or Indian lentils. Bring your friends to try this sustainable and organic meal!

The Mallards with The Swells

On Friday, April 13, from 8 p.m. to 12 a.m., The Mallards will be performing with The Swells on 6508 Del Playa Drive. Dress up in a spooky costume and stop by with friends to hear some groovy tunes. Those wearing the best costumes will get to dance on stage with both bands. The Swells will be performing at 9 p.m., and The Mallards will be performing at 10:30 p.m.

IVCSD Disaster Preparedness

Come participate in a conversation around disaster preparedness in Isla Vista hosted by the I.V. Community Services District on Friday, April 13, from 12:15 p.m. to 1:30 p.m in the Isla Vista Community Room. Learn about how you can be ready for a natural disaster from Isla Vista’s local government.

County Composting Workshop

Do you care about the environment? Do you want to learn more about how you can help the environment? If you answered “yes” to both of these questions, don’t forget to come to the County Composting Workshop hosted by the Isla Vista Food Co-Op on Saturday, April 14, from 12 p.m. to 1 p.m. The Associated Students Department of Public Worms and the Santa Barbara County Resource Recovery and Waste Management Division will be there to teach you about the kind of food that can be composted and the usage of worms. There will also be demonstrations with compost and earth machines. Bring your friends, enjoy some free snacks and learn about compost.

Grocery Shopping on a Budget

Are you unsure how to effectively budget your grocery money? On Monday, April 16, from 6 p.m. to 7 p.m., the Isla Vista Food Co-Op is hosting Grocery Shopping on a Budget, an event to teach students how to grocery shop on a budget of $50 a week. There will be demonstrations from the cookbook entitled “Good and Cheap: Eat Well on $4 a Day.” The Co-Op will be raffling off the cookbook at the event. Come learn how to utilize your grocery money wisely.

Free Tuesday Films: “The Disaster Artist”

Associated Students Program Board is hosting a free film called “The Disaster Artist” on Tuesday, April 17, from 6 p.m. to 9 p.m. at the I.V. Theatre. “The Disaster Artist” is about two friends who travel to Los Angeles and end up writing and directing their own movie. Bring your friends, some movie snacks and enjoy the film. Skip the movie theatre and swing by I.V. theatre.

The Global Environmental Justice Movement: Defining and Engaging

On Tuesday, April 17, Dr. David Pellow will be giving a talk on the global environmental justice movement from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m. at Rincon Brewery. Come learn about the future of the environmental justice movement and listen to Brengrass, which is a band of Bren school students. Not to mention, there will be free pizza. Swing by to get educated, eat some great food and listen to some groovy tunes.

A version of this story appeared on pg. 3 of the April 12, 2018 issue of the Daily Nexus.

Print

related.title: Vista Point: Weekly Goings-On in Isla Vista
related.description: VOTING ON GOLD BEGINS SOON UC Santa Barbara’s Associated Students Elections voting will begin on April 23 at 8 p.m. Students have the opportunity to vote their peers into senatorial positions as wel...
related.content:
Sierra Deak/Daily Nexus

VOTING ON GOLD BEGINS SOON

UC Santa Barbara’s Associated Students Elections voting will begin on April 23 at 8 p.m. Students have the opportunity to vote their peers into senatorial positions as well as five executive positions. The NewCen project will also be on the ballot; the project would drastically remodel the current university center as well as raise student fees. In addition, several existing fees will be up for reaffirmation. Voting continues until April 26 at 4 p.m., at which time the polls will close.

 

PRINCESS MONONOKE MEETING

The Isla Vista Food Co-op will screen Princess Mononoke, a 1997 Japanese animated historical fantasy film written and directed by Hayao Miyazaki. The movie centers around issues pertaining to the environment, and the screening will transition into Earth Day weekend! The movie will begin at 5:30 p.m. on Friday and will close around 8:30 p.m. Popcorn will be served, so pull up a chair! The co-op is located at 6575 Seville Rd. in Isla Vista.

 

FREE DENTAL DAY

Santa Barbara Neighborhood Clinics will team up with the Rotary Club of Santa Barbara Sunrise on Friday to offer free dental services at the Goleta Neighborhood Dental Clinic. Dentists, health professionals and community volunteers from the Santa Barbara County area will be gathered at 164 Kinman Avenue to offer treatments including exams, x-rays, extractions, fillings and cleanings. Patients do not need dental insurance and will be assigned an appointment time at registration. Go get clean teeth!

 

FRAT DOES 911 EMERGENCY PROTOCOL PANEL

UCSB’s fraternity Zeta Beta Tau will hold a 911 emergency protocol panel at I.V. Theater on Thursday from 5:30 p.m. Several representatives from both on and off campus organizations will be there to provide knowledge and first-hand experiences about what happens when an individual calls 911. Any member of the UCSB Greek system who attends will be given SOE credit, but the panel is open to all UCSB students who wish to attend and learn more about calling 911. The theater is located at 960 Embarcadero del Norte, and the panel will close at 6:30 p.m.

 

PITCH PERFECT 3

A.S. Program Board will be showing free films at I.V. Theater on Tuesdays throughout Spring Quarter until May 29. The program board will be showing “Pitch Perfect 3,” directed by Trish Sie, this upcoming Tuesday at 7 p.m. and 10 p.m. Anna Kendrick, Rebel Wilson and Brittany Snow reprise their roles as Beca, Amy and Chloe, respectively. All starred in “Pitch Perfect” and “Pitch Perfect 2,” a franchise that explores a struggling acapella group. The next movie program board will be showing is “Annihilation” on May 1.

Print

related.title: Gauchos Look To Stay Hot At Home
related.description: UCSB looks to extend its 12 game home winning streak when it faces off against Nevada today at 3 p.m.
related.content:
The No. 13 UCSB baseball team quickly shifts its attention to Nevada for a Monday afternoon match after a three-game conference series against CSUN this past weekend.

After hitting the ball into left field, Austin Bush runs to first base. Dustin Harris / Daily Nexus

The Gauchos host the quick one game series with an overall record of 24-7-1, 5-1 Big West record. Currently, they sit atop the conference standings although it is still early in the Big West season. Nevada comes into the game with a 15-18 overall record, 6-8 in its conference play and is in the midst of a five game losing streak.

As the wins keep coming for Santa Barbara, the national ranking has been improving as well. After sweeping CSUN, UCSB is now ranked No. 13 in the country.

By contrast, Nevada has not been ranked so far this year and its meeting with the Gauchos will be the first time it has faced a ranked opponent this season.

History has also not been on the Wolf pack’s side as this will be the 27th all-time meeting between Nevada and UCSB as Nevada trails the series history, 19-16.

In order to defeat such a quality opponent, Nevada will need to call upon its big players to step up and make big plays.

The Wolf pack has been pretty solid in some areas this year as it ranks first in the Mountain West conference in fielding percentage (.978) and ranks third in both batting average (.285) and ERA (4.66).

Sophomore outfielder Cole Krzmarzick leads the team in batting average (.414) while fellow sophomore teammate TJ Friedl ranks second in both batting average (.393) and RBI (16).

Senior third baseman Bryce Greager and junior shortstop Miles Mastrobuoni are both tied for first on the team in RBI (18) while the senior also leads the team in slugging percentage (.576).

Pitching wise, the Gauchos will be facing senior Zach Wilkins (3-3) who has struggled mightily this season posting a 6.95 ERA in a bit over 33 innings pitched. The right-hander has been unable to get out of the fourth inning in the last three games he’s started.

UCSB knows the way to get a victory in this one will be by taking advantage of a struggling pitcher with its exceptional hitting.

The Gauchos have been hitting the ball well as of late registering 29 hits against CSUN this past weekend and getting at least 10-plus hits in three of their last six games.

The great thing about Santa Barbara’s hitting is that it does not stem from one player but rather the entire team. Every game a new hitter can emerge and help his team pick up a win, something UCSB has done a lot this season.

One player who is coming in hot into this match-up is redshirt junior Andrew Calica. The center fielder had a solid series going 7-13 (.538), with three runs, two RBI and one home run. The junior leads the team in hits (34) and on-base percentage (.487).

Other big hitters include former Big West Players of the Week, sophomore Austin Bush who leads the team in RBI (24) and redshirt sophomore Josh Adams who leads the team in slugging percentage (.542) and is tied for first in home runs (4) with fellow redshirt sophomore J.J Muno.

On the mound for the Gauchos will be freshman Kyle Hatton (2-0). The left hander has won his only two starts of the season while registering a 1.93 ERA after pitching 14 innings and allowing 10 hits and three runs while striking out eight.

Although UCSB is probably a bit fatigued after a tough series against CSUN, it still has to come out and play hard against a team that wants to get back on track. It is still in the midst of one of the best starts in school history and cannot afford a loss to a team it should beat.

It also helps that Santa Barbara gets to stay at home as it currently has a 16-1 record including having won 12 straight, the second longest home winning streak in school history.

The Gauchos will face-off against the Wolf Pack Monday, April 18 at 3 p.m. at Caesar Uyesaka Stadium.

Print
Jorge Mercado

Jorge Mercado is the current Editor in Chief and was a Sports Editor before that since freshman year. He prefers to be called Merk as that was his nickname given to him by the gods. Sometimes, his evil twin Mork appears. Clear eyes, full hearts, can’t lose.
